The College is located in Cape Coast, Ghana, overlooking the Atlantic Ocean (Gulf of Guinea). Its campus covers an area of about 1.30 acres (52,6084 hectares), providing a conducive atmosphere for academic work. It's about 1.8 km from the Cape Coast Town Hall and about 2.3 km from the west gate of the University of Cape Coast along the beach.

patterns: How does the college coat of arms look like
How does the college crest look like
responses: The College Coat of Arms consists of a shield with a white cross on a green field. It symbolizes the College's commitment to purity and academic excellence. The shield also features lighted torches flanked by laurels, representing the College's leadership in academic progress and the reward of victory for its students. The green background signifies the College's dedication to total student development.

what courses are offered in the school

what programmes do we offer in the school
responses: The following academic courses are offered in the College: General Arts, Business, General Science, and Agricultural Science.

patterns: is it possible to change your course
how do i change my course
responses: A change of course or programme must first be approved by the parents of the student and further approved by the Assistant Headmaster (Academic), who will then discuss it with the Headmaster for final approval. Any such request should be made within the first term/semester or by the end of the academic year, otherwise, the student may be required to repeat the form.

patterns: how do i get my transcript
what do i need to get a tanscript
do i need to pay for transcripts
responses: Transcripts of academic records issued by the college are copies of the complete unabridged academic record of the student at the college. Requests for the issuance of transcripts must be accompanied by the complete name used by the student while in attendance, indicating any change in name if applicable, the dates of attendance, authority notes (duly signed by the student) if the student cannot be present in person, the complete mailing address including the name of the office or person to whom the transcript is to be sent, and the postage fee payable to the accounts department if the college will incur extra costs in doing so.

patterns: what are the department in the college?
what course sectors are in augusco
responses: There are four (4) Departments in the College. Each Department is under a Head of Department and the Units are headed by sector subject masters or mistresses. The departments are organized as follows: Department of Arts, Department of Science, Department of Agriculture, and Department of Business.

who is the head of ICT depaartment
responses: The Heads of Departments are: Mr. Dominic Adofo Mensah for General Science/Agric Science, Mr. Aloysius Donkor for Maths and IT, and Mercy Abban (Ms) for General Arts.

patterns: how do we call we call the past students
responses: The St. Augustine's Past Students Union (APSU) is an association for past students of St. Augustine's College. Once you become a student at the college, you begin a lifelong association with it. Past students keep in touch with their friends, houses of residence, course mates, clubs, and societies. The college likes to keep its graduates informed about its activities and development and is interested to know how they are doing. Upon graduating, you automatically become a member of APSU, so remember to keep the association's office updated with any change of address or occupation. They wish to continue to keep in touch with you.

patterns: What are the aims of APSU
What are the objectives and aims of the APSUNIANS
responses: The aims and objectives of the St. Augustine's Past Students Union (APSU) are to enable past students to maintain their links with the College, promote social contacts and networking among its members, and promote the welfare of past and present students of the College.

patterns: What are the branches of APSU
I want to know about the APSU branches
responses: The St. Augustine's Past Students Union (APSU) has well-established local branches in Accra, Kumasi, Sekondi-Takoradi, Tema, and Cape Coast. New branches are also emerging in other parts of the country, including Koforidua, Sunyani, and Ho. Additionally, APSU has branches in the United States of America, Canada, South Africa, and parts of Europe. The National Secretariat is located in Accra. Furthermore, there are branches in all the Polytechnics and universities in Ghana, including Takoradi Technical University, Accra Technical University, Kumasi Technical University, University of Ghana, University of Cape Coast, Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST), University of Mines and Technology, and University of Education, Winneba.
The current senior prefect is Master Aboagye Louis

patterns: What does the senoir prefect do
What are the duties of the obligations
responses: The Senior Prefect holds the highest prefect position in the college. They oversee student behavior, settle disputes, organize prefects' meetings, act as a liaison between students and authorities, ensure student welfare, maintain hygienic conditions, report irregularities, and provide feedback on staff performance.

patterns: What are the subjects under the department of arts
What subjects are general arts department
responses: The Department of Arts includes English, French Literature in English, Geography History, Government, Social Studies, Religious and Moral Education, Christian Religious Studies, and Music.

patterns: What subjects are under the science department
responses: The Department of Science includes Physics, Chemistry, Biology, Physical Education, Mathematics (both core and elective), and Information Communication and Technology (ICT).

patterns: What are the subjects in agriculture department
responses: The Department of Agriculture includes Animal Husbandry and General Agriculture.

patterns: What subjects are in the department of business
responses: The Department of Business includes Economics, Accounting, Cost Accounting, and Introduction to Business Management.

patterns: What are the core subject offered
What are the number of core subjects
responses: The core subjects include English Language, Mathematics, Integrated Science, and Social Studies. Additionally, students take Religious and Moral Education, ICT, and Physical Education, although these are not externally examined.

patterns: What are the elective subjects to be chosen
What elective subjects can I choose
responses:
For General Arts - 1,
 students can choose from Music, Christian Religious Studies (CRS), French, Elective Mathematics, or any two of Economics, Geography, and Government.
For General Arts - 2,
students must take Music, Christian Religious Studies (CRS), French, and either History or Literature-In-English, along with any other two subjects.
In the Business stream, students can select Accounting, Economics, Costing/Elective Mathematics, or Business Management.
In the Science stream, students can choose Physics, Chemistry, Elective Mathematics, Biology, or Elective ICT or Geography.
For Agricultural Science, students take Animal Husbandry, General Agriculture, Physics, and Chemistry.

patterns: How many classes are n the school
What are the classes in the school
responses: The college has a total of 19 classes for SHS 1, 18 for SHS 2, and 21 for SHS 3, with an average class size of 54 students. The distribution of courses/programmes is as follows: SHS 1 - General Science (10), Business (3), General Arts (5), Agricultural Science (1); SHS 2 - General Science (10), Business (3), General Arts (4), Agricultural Science (1); SHS 3 - General Science (11), Business (4), General Arts (5), Agricultural Science (1).

patterns: How many courses does the school offers
How many programmes are in the school
What programmes does the school offers
responses: The candidate's choice of programme is respected as much as possible. However, factors such as performance in the Basic Education Certificate Examination (BECE) and available space are taken into consideration. Final decisions on placements are made by the Academic Board of the College in consultation with the guidance and counseling coordinator. Computer placements of candidates into programmes are submitted to the school.

responses: The Student Representative Council is a group in St. Augustine's College that represents the whole student body at the administrative level by raising students concern on certain issuses and problems they face on campus.

The Student Representative Council consists of a group of students that include all prefects, representative from each class, and representative from each club. It is headed by the SRC president who is appointted by the group each year.

responses: We have won two, in 2007 and 2019

St. Augustine, also known as Augustine of Hippo, was an early Christian theologian and philosopher whose writings influenced the development of Western Christianity and Western philosophy.Birth: Augustine was born on November 13, 354, in Thagaste (modern-day Souk Ahras, Algeria), in the Roman province of Numidia.Family: His mother, Monica, was a devout Christian, while his father, Patricius, was a pagan who converted to Christianity on his deathbed.Studies: Augustine studied rhetoric in Carthage, where he became acquainted with Latin literature, philosophy, and the art of public speaking.Manichaeism: For a time, he was a follower of Manichaeism, a religion that taught a dualistic view of good and evil.Bishop of Hippo: Augustine became the Bishop of Hippo (modern-day Annaba, Algeria) in 395, a position he held until his death.Death: Augustine died on August 28, 430, during the siege of Hippo by the Vandals.St. Augustine is remembered as one of the most important figures in the history of Christianity, whose ideas shaped the theological landscape of the Western world.

patterns: What is the history of the college
responses: On 6 August 1933, the Roman Catholic Church and the Bishop of Cape Coast Vicariate Monsignor W. T. Porter felt the need to have a separate Roman Catholic school and Cape Coast was found to be the most suitable location.A commemorative foundation stone was laid in late 1935 at the present site. Fr. Maurice B. Kelly, the Dean of the Training College at Amissano which is now St. Teresa’s Seminary, Amisano,became the first Head Dean or Headmaster.
